author: Khulekani Magubane
title: Changes to public sector wage negotiations mooted | Economy
text:
Finance Minister Nhlanhla Nene, right, and Deputy Finance Minister Mncebisi Jonas at a media briefing ahead of the medium-term budget policy statement on Wednesday. Picture: TREVOR SAMSON Related articles The medium-term budget policy in a nutshell Cape Town students swarm Parliament over fee increases Related multimedia BUSINESS DAY TV: Numbers likely to be better for this fiscal year In this article People: Nhlanhla Nene THE Treasury is considering radical changes to how public sector wage negotiations are conducted, after concluding a three-year pay agreement in 2015 that has created a R12.2bn hole in the compensation budget.
Finance Minister Nhlanhla Nene has warned that the government cannot afford above-inflation wage increases as it enters into a belt-tightening phase that will see state posts frozen, among other cost-containment measures, to arrest a runaway deficit.
Mr Nene said in Parliament on Wednesday that the government would introduce reforms that would see public sector pay linked to performance. In addition, collective bargaining would have to factor "resource constraints".
Related files PDF: Medium-term budget policy statement 2015
Treasury deputy director-general Michael Sachs said provincial departments had to tailor their budgets accordingly, as well as make room for critical skills.
The Treasury expects the compensation budget shortfall to reach R20.6bn in the 2016-17 financial year, and R31.1bn in 2017-18.
